snippet: When a museum faces a demand that it give up an item, it must consider its public relations needs, the donor of the disputed item and even the country that is asking for its return.
abstract: Museums may repatriate items to countries that claim ownership but must consider public relations needs, donor of disputed item and even identity of country that is asking for its return; compares case of Metropolitan Museum of Art, which returned statues to Cambodia within one year of request, and dispute between J Paul Getty Museum and Turkey, who have been fighting over fifth-century bronze bed since 1995.
lead_paragraph: When a museum faces a demand that it give up an item, it must consider its public relations needs, the donor of the disputed item and even the country that is asking for its return.

headline.seo: Museums’ Property Claims Are Not Simply About Evidence
headline.main: No Quick Answers in Fights Over Art
headline.print_headline: No Quick Answers In Fights Over Art

keywords.value: University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology
keywords.name: organizations
